title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #99: Equilateral Triangles in Minimal Diameter Sets**

Given n points in ℝ² with minimum distance 1, chosen to minimize diameter:
Must large n force a unit equilateral triangle?

**Status:** OPEN
**Prize:** $100 (counterexample), $50 (proof)

Erdős offered MORE for a counterexample — he suspected it might be false!
mathContext: Thue proved optimal 2D packing uses the triangular lattice. The conjecture asks if this global structure forces local triangular substructure.

title: The Euclidean Plane
content:
**Plane:** ℝ² = EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)

**dist p q:** The Euclidean distance ‖p - q‖.

The natural setting for the packing problem.

title: Minimum Pairwise Distance
content:
**minPairwiseDistance A:** The smallest distance between distinct points in A.

The constraint is minPairwiseDistance A ≥ 1.

Equivalently: unit disks centered at points don't overlap.

title: Diameter
content:
**diameter A:** The largest distance between any two points in A.

The optimization goal: minimize diameter subject to min distance ≥ 1.

This forces efficient packing of points.

title: Unit Equilateral Triangle
content:
**IsUnitEquilateralTriangle p q r:** All three pairwise distances equal 1.

dist p q = dist q r = dist r p = 1

These are the fundamental building blocks of the triangular lattice.

title: Optimal Configuration
content:
**IsOptimalConfiguration A:**

1. HasMinDistanceOne A (min pairwise distance ≥ 1)
2. HasMinimalDiameter A (smallest diameter among all such sets)

These are the configurations the conjecture asks about.

title: Triangular Lattice
content:
**TriangularLattice:** Points with coordinates (i + j/2, j√3/2) for i, j ∈ ℤ.

Basis vectors: (1, 0) and (1/2, √3/2).

This is the optimal 2D packing lattice (Thue's theorem).

title: Lattice Contains Equilateral Triangles
content:
**triangular_lattice_has_equilateral:**

Any three adjacent points in the triangular lattice form a unit equilateral triangle.

This is why the conjecture seems plausible: if configurations resemble the lattice, they should contain triangles.

title: Thue's Theorem
content:
**thue_optimal_packing:**

The densest packing of unit circles in ℝ² is the triangular (hexagonal) lattice.

Density = π/(2√3) ≈ 0.9069.

Consequence: diameter-minimizing configurations should resemble the triangular lattice.

title: The n=4 Counterexample
content:
**case_n4_square:**

For n = 4, the square with vertices at distance 1 apart is optimal but contains NO unit equilateral triangle!

This shows the conjecture fails for small n and suggests counterexamples might exist for larger n too.

title: The Main Conjecture
content:
**Erdos99Conjecture:**

∃ N, ∀ n ≥ N, all optimal n-point configurations contain a unit equilateral triangle.

This is the main OPEN problem.

title: Stronger Conjecture
content:
**StrongerConjecture:**

For all ε > 0, large optimal configurations have (1-ε)n points lying exactly on the triangular lattice.

This implies the main conjecture but is much stronger.

title: Prize Asymmetry
content:
**prize_asymmetry:** prizeCounterexample > prizeProof

$100 for counterexample vs $50 for proof.

Erdős offered MORE money for a counterexample — suggesting he believed the conjecture might be FALSE.

Sendov and Simonovits also doubted it.

title: Problem Summary
content:
**erdos_99_summary:**

1. The main conjecture asks about unit equilateral triangles in optimal configurations
2. n = 4 square shows small cases can avoid triangles
3. Prize: $100 counterexample, $50 proof

**Status:** OPEN — prize unclaimed
